pages.text: Hylaecullulus fordi comes from the Upper Ediacaran, with fossils found in the Charnwood Forest, UK. It is a lifeform comprised of many leaf-like shapes joined together by a central rod, and could grow up to 38 cm in height, and possibly partook in filter feeding from the surrounding water.

Hylaecullulus is known to have the largest holdfast to body ratio of all petalonamae, which garnered the nickname of 'The Dumbbell'. The generic name derives from the Greek Words 'hylaeos', to mean 'from the woods'; and 'cullulus', to mean 'small goblet'. Its specific name derives from the surname of Trevor Ford, a well known Ediacaran Palaeontologist.
